snippet: James Comey says most of the right things before the Senate Judiciary Committee, but questions remain about his commitment to civil liberties.
abstract: Editorial holds that James Comey, Pres Obama's nominee to head Federal Bureau of Investigation, said most of the right things before Senate Judiciary Committee; asserts, however, that his tenure as deputy attorney general in George W Bush's administration raises important questions about his commitment to civil liberties and his independence in an office that demands unstinting devotion to both principles.
lead_paragraph: James Comey says most of the right things before the Senate Judiciary Committee, but questions remain about his commitment to civil liberties.

headline.main: A New Leader for the F.B.I.
headline.print_headline: A New Leader for the F.B.I.
